flowRoot.flowPara: Teaching a Class to Grade Itself Using Game Theory

In recent years, MOOCs (Massive Open Online Courses) such as Coursera or EdX have been gaining popularity. More importantly, MOOC systems are able to educate massive numbers of students from anywhere in the world, which leads to problems: professors are simply unable to grade the hundreds of thousands of submissions. One common solution, automated grading, relies on machines to grade assignments. Machines can only grade certain types of problem (i.e. multiple choice), limiting the depth of the questions asked. Although automated essay grading is an active area of research, the quality and accuracy of such systems is still under heavy debate. Peer grading can grade any type of question, but can easily be "hacked" by clever students. A definitive solution has yet to be found that can efficiently and accurately evaluate students' mastery of the course material.

We propose several peer grading systems using game theory and mechanism design, backed by a rigorous mathematical analysis of the system. By defining constraints that a grading system must satisfy to mitigate students' incentive to cheat and by creating a benchmark to analyze the efficiency of various systems, we allow for comparison between different systems in terms of efficiency for the class and fairness for the students. In general, mechanisms that do not follow game theoretic constraints may work in the short-term, but will be exploited if possible in the long term.
Workload / Objective Function vs Various Mechanisms
Take off no points on one paper
Take off a fair number points on one paper
Partner takes more pts and gets refuted

To begin our project, we created a model, based on a set of assumptions, that was incredibly simple. Over time, however, our model evolved and became more complicated, eventually reaching the state that it is in now. Currently, our assumptions are as follows:
1) Students have a happiness function H(g) that takes their grade as input, and outputs a value such that H(0)=0
3) Grading one paper costs 1 unit of energy, which corresponds to one unit of happiness. Final happiness = H(G) - W where W is work done/papers graded
4) Final happiness is based purely on grade and work done, nothing else such as other people
5) For any given student in class C, they have contact with all other members of C

7) Students can either grade a paper or not grade it. They cannot put in some halfway effort. Effort spent per paper is 0 or 8) Graders know their own margin of error, they have some uncertainty factor U. More skilled graders have a lower U value.
9) The more effort a grader expends, the lower U will become
10) When a grader assigns a grade G, the likelihood of the actual grade being G+N gets lower as N gets higher at a rate proportional to their value of U.

To show that any of our mechanisms are better than existing ones, we need a way to measure their efficiency and accuracy. To do this we created a benchmark score. The Benchmark score takes the maximum amount of work done by one person and the most incorrect grade as input, and sums them as output. This means that the lower the benchmark, the better the mechanism. In mathematical terms, this equation is expressed as:

As a long term goal, we would like to see our mechanisms and models implemented in an actualy MOOC such as Edx or Coursera. Looking towards the short term, we intend to develop a mechanism based on the assumptions gathered from mechanical turk, and to also make that mechanism work more efficiently than any before it. We would then like to polish our assumptions and make them more realistic. In addition, we plan to run additional trials on mechanical turk to further confirm our assumptions. We also want to get started on an implementation that we can test somewhere, be it at school or with friends. All in all, we bascially want to create a more realistic model, a very effective and efficient mechanism, and we want to implement both of these in an actual online course system. As another goal, we would like to see our model be used by others to create their own solutions.

In this research, we set out to create a set of realistic assumptions that would allow us to predict how students act in a classroom environment, while also creating a set of mechanisms that take advantage of this and incentivize students to do what we want; stay honest and grade efficiently. In our first goal, we had what we feel is a very good sucess. This is important to us as it allows people to use our mechanisms to create their own solutions to this problem. This does not mean that our model is finalized by any means, but it is very far along, and we feel that it is quite strong. The second goal is not as far along sadly, but we feel that the mechanisms that we developed are still an important result, and that they show strong results. They fit very well into a less realistic system, and cannot truly be implemented unless they are in a much smaller classroom where the professor can exercise more control. In addition to this we used the new Mechanical Turk tool to crowdsource our experiments, allowing us to confirm the assumptions we made, which helps validate our model and mechanisms in the eyes of other game theorists.
This mechanism achieves a benchmark score of 4, which is very low, as the greatest deviation is 2, and the greatest amount of work done by any one person is also 2. 2+2=4.

This mechanism is extremely simple, and relies on the unrealistic assumption that students are unable to communicate with each other. If they were able to, students would be able to figure out which paper is calibrated by checking which one they all share.
This mechanism achieves a benchmark score of 2, which is very low, as the greatest deviation is 0, and the greatest amount of work done by any one person is 2. 2+0=2.

This mechanism is far more complex than the last one created, but is actually more efficient. In a classroom environment where the professor has very high control over the class, and all the students are very capable graders as the mechanism does not account for incompetent graders
